alternative_title: Employers' tax and reporting for personal and business expenses
overview: Tax and reporting rules for employers who meet or reimburse an employee's expenses, including scale rate payments and round sum allowances
title: Expenses and benefits: cash sum payments to employees

table.body:
As an employer providing business or private expenses for your employees, you have certain tax, National Insurance and reporting obligations.

^There are separate rules for individual benefits you provide to your employees. You need to follow specific [reporting and payment rules for different items](/expenses-and-benefits-a-to-z "Expenses and benefits A to Z"), including [travel](/expenses-and-benefits-travel "travel"), [meals](/expenses-and-benefits-meals-for-employees-and-directors "meals") and [accommodation](/expenses-and-benefits-accommodation "accommodation").^

##What's included

The rules on cash sum payments for [business expenses](/expenses-and-benefits-cash-sum-payments/rules-for-business-expenses "business expenses") cover:

- cash sums you provide to meet the costs of your employees' expenses
- expenses they've paid for themselves that you reimburse
- '[scale rate payments](/expenses-and-benefits-cash-sum-payments/scale-rate-payments "scale rate payments")' you pay at a level agreed with HMRC
- '[round sum allowances](/expenses-and-benefits-cash-sum-payments/round-sum-allowances "round sum allowances")', which you give to an employee regardless of how they spend them

^Payments for [private expenses](/expenses-and-benefits-cash-sum-payments/rules-for-private-expenses "private expenses") count as earnings.^

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Overview

table.body:
In general, something only counts as a business expense if your employee needs it to do their job. You don't have to deduct or pay tax and National Insurance on qualifying business expenses, but you need to make sure that they meet all of HMRC's criteria for:

- [employees' business expenses (tax)](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/eimanual/eim31630.htm "employees' business expenses (tax)"){:rel="external"}

- [employees' business expenses (National Insurance)](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/nimmanual/nim05020.htm "employees' business expenses (National Insurance)"){:rel="external"}

##Business travel

Costs relating to business travel also count as business expenses, unless the travel is in the employee's own vehicle. 

For more details, see the guides on:

- [travel expenses](/expenses-and-benefits-travel "travel expenses")
- [business travel mileage for employees' own vehicles](/expenses-and-benefits-business-travel-mileage "business travel mileage for employees' own vehicles")

##What to report and pay

You don't need to report or pay anything if you provide business expenses for employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 a year.

For employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of more than £8,500 a year:

- you'll need to report the cost of the expenses on form P11D, section N -- unless you have a dispensation covering them
- you don't need to deduct or pay any tax or National Insurance

^You can [apply for a dispensation](/apply-for-a-dispensation "apply for a dispensation") to cover some business expenses. This means you won’t have to include them in your end-of-year reports.^

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Rules for business expenses

table.body:
Private expenses are anything that doesn't count as a [business expense](/expenses-and-benefits-cash-sum-payments/rules-for-business-expenses "business expense"), eg the cost of any travel that isn't necessary for your employee to do their job.

If you cover the costs of private expenses, this counts as earnings. You'll need to:

- add the amount to your employee's other earnings
- deduct and pay PAYE tax and Class 1 National Insurance through payroll

*[PAYE]:Pay As You Earn
table.title: Rules for private expenses

table.body:
If you provide your employees with a set amount of cash for some common business expenses like travel and meals, these are known as 'scale rate payments'. 

As long as your employee has actually spent the scale rate payment on business expenses, you won't need to check every single receipt -- it's fine to just [check a sample.](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/eimanual/EIM05210.htm "scale rate sampling guidance"){:rel="external"}

You can set up a scale rate payment by either:

- [agreeing a scale rate with HMRC](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/eimanual/eim05200.htm "agree on a scale rate with HMRC"){:rel="external"} by providing evidence of typical expenses (eg receipts)
- using [HMRC's benchmark scale rates](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/eimanual/EIM05231.htm "HMRC's benchmark scale rates"){:rel="external"} for subsistence costs

^HMRC also provides benchmark rates for [employees travelling outside of the UK.](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/eimanual/eim05250.htm "employees travelling outside of the UK"){:rel="external"}^

##What to report and pay

You don't need to report or pay anything if you provide scale rate payments for employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 a year.

For employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or more a year:

- you'll need to report scale rate payments on form P11D, section N -- unless you have a dispensation covering them
- you don't need to deduct or pay any tax or National Insurance

^You can [apply for a dispensation](/apply-for-a-dispensation “apply for a dispensation) to cover scale rate payments. This means you won’t have to include them in your end-of-year reports.^

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Scale rate payments

table.body:
If you provide a set amount of cash for employees regardless of how they spend it, this is known as a 'round sum allowance'.

This counts as earnings, so you'll need to:

- add the full amount of the round sum allowance to the employee's other earnings when deducting and paying PAYE tax through payroll
- add the amount of the round sum allowance -- minus any specific business expenses covered by it -- to the employee's other earnings when deducting and paying Class 1 National Insurance through payroll

*[PAYE]:Pay As You Earn
